glossary.Description: A list of resources that are referenced in your work. These should be written in a citation format.
An online dairy of personal notes.
A reference to a resource such as a website or a book. Citations are written in a particular format such as the APA or the MLA.
Information that everybody knows in a community or group.
A particular order of structure of something such as a citation.

A brief citation that appears in the text of your paper that allows the reader to know the source of your references. All in-text citations must be accompanied by their full citations in the bibliography.
A magazine that is written around a specific subject. E.g. An archeology journal.
The re-writing of what somebody has said or written. When you paraphrase, remember to cite the source.
The act of stealing somebody else’s work or ideas and passing it off as your own.
A sentence or phrase taken from somebody else’s work and reproduced as it is (without changing the words).
Mentioning or pointing out to somebody else’s work or ideas.
The person or thing from where you got information or ideas from.
To re-write a long article or a book in a shorter format.
A particular way of doing a task or activity. E.g. the technique of rowing a boat, or writing a research paper.
A free online encyclopedia available at http://www.wikipedia.com/
A video-sharing website available at http://www.youtube.com/
